ratings.comment: Amy is a blast and CSD424 is such a fun class. She makes learning about sign language and deaf culture so interesting. She is always willing to chat before and after class. She's so knowledgeable & kind if you have questions or comments. Class is great because it's very low-stress. I love that Amy brings in local deaf/HH people for interviews.

She's an interpreter on campus and knows what it's like to learn sign language. Easily one of the best and easiest classes I've taken. Brings in guest speakers and tries to make lectures interesting yet beneficial. Currently have a 105% in the class thanks to extra credit. As someone who's taking math, o-chem, and bio this class is saving my sanity

One of my favorite classes! Learned a lot more than I thought I would and didn't feel nervous about where I was in my learning. Free gave a lot of opportunities for XC and for extra learning that really helped. I def recommend this class and this professor!

CSD 424 was by far the easiest, yet most interesting, class I have ever taken. I got a 105% in the class due to extra credit and only went to lecture maybe once every other week because I work night shift. Amy is an incredibly kind soul who is super passionate about activism in the d/Deaf community. She makes the class easy to get an A.

Amy Free was a great professor for an introduction to ASL! She is very clear on what she expects from students. It is easy to do well in class if you go to lectures. Sign time is a great way to get extra practice if you want but unnecessary to get a good grade in the class. Exams online and in person.

Very easy and seems very nice, but if you ever have to talk to her in person beware. Not nice out of class and on email. Spent a lot of time complaining about having to teach the class, talked to a group of people that she was not a part of, and will call you out if you don't know the answer to something. She demands respect but never has earned it

Prof. Free was a really good professor. I came into 424 with little knowledge of ASL or the Deaf community, but she helped me feel comfortable in my signing and understanding of ASL. There were readings and "sign times" where we would watch her sign and then sign back. There were a few quizzes, an exam, and a final - all passable if you go to class

Amy Free is the best! As someone who came in with very little ASL experience, she made the class very accesible and learning new topics about ASL and the Deaf community every week was exciting and inspiring. Shes super receptive to questions and is available when you need her - and she gets work back very quickly, so thats a huge plus!
